CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 29, 1952, pg. 13, reads:" Negro Clerks, Cashier Become Fashion on Homewood Avenue - When Donahoe's new store on Homewood Avenue opened its doors this week, six Negroes took jobs in store, thanks to the forward-looking Donahoe Store management and the campaign conducted by the Greater Pittsburgh Improvement League which has also secured jobs for a Negro cashier-clerk at another store, Vilsack-Ray's on the same street. The GPIL has also secured clerk-cashier jobs for Negroes at several other chain stores throughout the city, including the Thorofare Supermarket at the intersections of Lincoln Avenue, Frankstown Avenue and Lowell Street in East Liberty.  In the left picture, Miss Helen Smith, one of the cashiers at the new Donahoe store, the front of which is shown in the second photo, waits on an anonymous white customer, one of the many thousands she serves during the day.  In the right picture, another clerk, James Hill, receives instructions from Mr. Donahoe, manager of the store, and a relative of the owners of the chain, as to the amount of stock needed, the specials for the day, and other matters Mr. Hill will need to know in waiting on trade."
TitMainTitle: Manager Mr. Donahoe holding Karo Syrup and standing with clerk James Hill wearing a "Donahoe's 577" badge, in Donahoe's Grocery store on Homewood Avenue
